title: Smallcap investor Anil Kumar Goel made multibagger returns on 1/3rd of portfolio stocks in 2017
summary: Goel had in 2014 predicted the beginning of the “mother of all bull runs” in 2016-17.
article: NEW DELHI:  Anil Kumar  Goel, who holds stakes in at least 34 BSE-listed smallcap companies, has seen 12 of his portfolio  stocks  rise 100 per cent to 250 per cent this calendar.   A renowned value investor, Goel had in 2014 predicted the beginning of the “mother of all bull runs” in 2016-17. Data suggests 19 of Goel's portfolio stocks have beaten  BSE  smallcap index’s 53 per cent return year to date (YTD).   Among his portfolio stocks,  Panama Petrochem  where the ace investor has exposure at least since 2010, has rallied 254 per cent so far this calendar. The company manufactures and exports specialty petroleum products.   IG Petrochems has seen its  shares  surge 212 per cent during the same period. Goel has stake in this firm at least since 2015. This company makes phthalic anhydride (PAN) used in industries such as flexible PVC, plastics, paints, construction, transportation and marine.   The Chennai-based investor held 5.38 per cent stake in sugar manufacturer  Uttam Sugar Mills , as of September 30. The scrip rallied 211 per cent this year. The investor has been holding this stock at least since the March quarter of 2017.   Investors always get caught in the fancy expensive counters during bull runs but failed to see quality stocks that have not kept pace with the broader  market , Goel told ET earlier this year.   Among others, Vardhman Special Steel (168 per cent),  Indsil Hydro  (162 per cent), Thuirumalai Chemicals (154.39 per cent),  JBM Auto  (133 per cent),  Dhampur Sugar  (137 per cent) and  Punjab Alkalies  (114 per cent) are some of its portfolio stocks that offered more than doubled the benchmark return.   During the September quarter, Goel cut his stake in  Amarjothi Spinning Mills  to 2.96 per cent in the September quarter from 4.65 per cent stake in the June quarter, data showed.      Goel largely maintained his holdings in a dozen companies such as  Dwarikesh Sugar , GRP, Indsil Hydro, L G Balakrishnan, Panama Petrochem,  TCPL Packaging  and Technocraf Industries, data from corporate database Capitaline showed.   Goel (4.21 per cent) and his wife Seema (1.60 per cent) made no change in their holdings in  Dwarikesh Sugar Industries  during the quarter.   He was seen trimming exposure to  Thirumalai Chemicals  to 216,000 shares, or 2.11 per cent, in Q2 from 230,000 shares, or 2.25 per cent in Q1.

title: Corporate Radar: TCS, SBI to go ex-dividend; GMM Pfaudler to consider bonus issue
summary: At least four stocks will go ex-dividend today. It includes TCS, which had announced a final dividend of Rs 22 per share recently. SBI, which announced a final dividend of Rs 7.10 per share, will also go ex-dividend today. Two others -- GRM Overseas and Qgo Finance -- which announced dividend (interim) per share of Re 0.25 and Re 0.10, respectively, will go ex-dividend today.
article: NEW DELHI: A host of quarterly earnings, board meetings and  corporate actions  are scheduled for Wednesday.  At least four stocks will go ex-dividend today. It includes  TCS , which had announced a final dividend of Rs 22 per share recently.  SBI , which announced a final dividend of Rs 7.10 per share, will also go ex-dividend today. Two others --  GRM Overseas  and Qgo Finance -- which announced dividend (interim) per share of Re 0.25 and Re 0.10, respectively, will go ex-dividend today.  The day will see ITI considering a preferential issue, along with its quarterly results.  GMM Pfaudler  and Xpro India will consider dividend and bonus while announcing their results today.  TCPL Packaging ,  Som Datt Finance Corporation ,  Shekhawati Poly Yarn  and Eco-Friendly Food Processing are some of the companies having their AGMs today.  Coal India, BPCL,  InterGlobe Aviation ,  Apollo Hospitals ,  Torrent Pharma ,  Max Healthcare , NHPC,  Power Finance Corporation , Bata India and  Fortis Healthcare  are some companies scheduled to report their March quarter results today.  Nalco, SJVN,  Bank of Maharashtra , Asahi India,  Easy Trip Planners ,  Suzlon Energy , MOIL, MSTC and Shalby are some other companies scheduled to report quarterly earnings.  Meanwhile,  Chandra Prabhu International  may consider a stock split today.

title: Share price of ACC jumps as Sensex gains 447.79 points
summary: Promoters held 50.05 per cent stake in the company as of 30-Jun-2022, while FII and DII ownership stood at 12.11 per cent and 9.38 per cent, respectively.
article: The share price of  ACC Ltd . gained 1.26 per cent to Rs 2388.6 at 01:34PM (IST) in Thursday's trade. The scrip has hit a high of Rs 2397.95 and low of Rs 2345.0 so far during the session. The stock had closed at Rs 2358.85 in the previous session.    The counter has had a total traded volume of 14859 shares so far with a value of Rs 3.53 crore on the  NSE . It traded at a price-to-earnings multiple of 32.7 and a price-to-book ratio of 2.91.    A higher price-to-earnings ratio shows investors are willing to pay a higher price for per rupee earnings given by the stock because of better future growth expectations.    The price-to-book value indicates the inherent value of a company and reflects the price investors are willing to pay even for no growth in the business.    The scrip gained 5.49 per cent during the past one year, while the 30-share index slipped -0.44 per cent during the same period.     ACC  Ltd. belongs to the Cement - Pan India industry.     Promotor/FII Holding   Promoters held 50.05 per cent stake in the company as of 30-Jun-2022, while FIIs and domestic institutional investors ownership stood at 12.11 per cent and 9.38 per cent, respectively.     Key Financials   The company reported consolidated net sales of Rs 4522.28 crore for the quarter ended 30-Jun-2022, up 0.83 per cent from the previous quarter's Rs 4485.01 crore and up 15.06 per cent from the year-ago quarter's Rs 3930.49 crore.    Profit for the latest quarter stood at Rs 227.32 crore, down 60.08 per cent from the same quarter a year ago.

title: CLSA prefers UltraTech over Ambuja Cements. Here’s why
summary: The Adani Group completed the acquisition of Ambuja Cements and its subsidiary ACC from Switzerland’s Holcim Group for $6.4 billion in the last month.The CLSA said the cement sector is likely to be at a multi-quarter low in 2QFY23, on lower prices and higher costs. “We expect margins to recover in 3QFY23 on lower fuel prices and benefits of operating leverage,” it said.
article: After Adani's entry into the cement space,  CLSA  on Thursday said it prefers  UltraTech  over Ambuja. The global brokerage has a buy rating on Ultra Tech Cement with a target price of Rs 7,200, a potential upside of 14.4% from the current market price of Rs 6,292.  The Adani Group completed the acquisition of  Ambuja Cements  and its subsidiary  ACC  from Switzerland’s Holcim Group for $6.4 billion in the last month.  The CLSA said the cement sector is likely to be at a multi-quarter low in 2QFY23, on lower prices and higher costs. “We expect margins to recover in 3QFY23 on lower fuel prices and benefits of operating leverage,” it said.   The brokerage believes cement demand has increased by high single-digit YoY on a base of 6% YoY in 2QFY22. This implies a three-year CAGR of 6-8%, it said.  CLSA’s channel checks suggest that cement prices are down 3- 6% quarter-on-quarter (QoQ) across regions, slightly higher than normal seasonality. Price declines have been greater in North and Central India compared to other regions, it said, adding that there has been some attempt to raise prices in November.  “The demand outlook and price increase post festive season (end October) would be key to watch for. Over the medium term, with utilisations remaining low, the price increase would be difficult to come by despite increasing consolidation. UltraTech (O-PF) is our preferred pick given its return accretive growth,” CLSA added.    (Disclaimer: Recommendations, suggestions, views, and opinions given by the experts are their own. These do not represent the views of Economic Times)

title: Q2 may see nifty revenue growth by Nifty 50 companies
summary: Second-quarter earnings will be led by the banking and finance, consumer, and automobile sectors and dragged down by commodity sectors such as metals and oil and gas, said Gautam Duggad, institutional research head, Motilal Oswal Financial Services. "We expect companies in our coverage universe and Nifty earnings excluding metals and oil and gas to post a 30% year-on-year growth in the September quarter," he said.
article: Mumbai: The aggregate  revenue  of the  Nifty  50 firms in the July-September period is likely to grow in double digits for the seventh quarter in a row. However, net profit  growth  may moderate to single-digit levels as  earnings  slow at some  companies  in the oil and gas, automobiles, metals, and pharma sectors. According to ETIG estimates, the sample's revenue is expected to grow 18.8% from the year earlier while net profit may increase 5%.  Stocking up of goods before the festive season may help top line growth, going by the GST and advance tax collections, said Deepak Jasani, retail research head,  HDFC  Securities.  The September quarter results could bring in a moderate rise in top line year-on-year and sequential basis," he said, while indicating that profitability will be tricky to forecast considering the inflation factor.  Second-quarter earnings will be led by the banking and finance, consumer, and automobile sectors and dragged down by commodity sectors such as metals and oil and gas, said Gautam Duggad, institutional research head,  Motilal Oswal Financial Services . "We expect companies in our coverage universe and  Nifty earnings  excluding metals and oil and gas to post a 30% year-on-year growth in the September quarter," he said.  According to ETIG estimates, the sample's operating margin is likely to shrink by 290 basis points year-on-year to 18.4% following high input cost inflation.    Areas of Concern    On the positive side, there may be a 50 basis point improvement in margins from the previous quarter, reflecting the effect of softening commodity prices. A basis point is 0.01 percentage point.  In the coming quarters, analysts expect demand to improve amid concerns over expectations of a recession in the western economies, the rupee depreciating further against the dollar and rising domestic interest rates.  We expect healthy corporate earnings momentum to continue. India's interest rate and currency management has been very strong compared with global central banks," Duggad said, while highlighting elevated crude oil prices and escalation in geopolitical tensions as concern areas.  Jasani expects another round of minor downgrades in the Nifty 50 earnings per share after the second-quarter results season as analysts cut back aggressive projections of profit growth due to raw material inflation effect.   Sector Outlook    Automobiles   It will be a mixed bag for the auto sector. The passenger car companies will post superior earnings growth thanks to the low base effect and a slight margin improvement.  Maruti Suzuki 's volume grew 42% year-on-year while M&M and  Tata Motors  both were among those showing the highest quarterly passenger vehicle volumes. However, muted domestic and export demand may curb earnings growth of two-wheeler companies barring  Eicher Motors .   Banking, finance   The September quarter was marked by better retail and small and medium enterprise (SME) credit offtake while deposit growth remained muted. Since private banks have a higher proportion of repo rate-linked loans, further increases in the policy rate are expected to benefit their net interest margins more than public sector banks. Asset quality is expected to be stable.   Cement   For the September 2022 quarter, large cement companies are likely to focus on volume growth given high input costs. Revenues of  Ultratech Cement ,  ACC ,  Ambuja Cements ,  Shree Cement  and Dalmia Bharat are likely to grow 11-14% year-on-year. Net profit may increase 15-20% because of effective cost management and the low base effect.   FMCG   FMCG companies are expected to show value-led revenue growth for the September quarter as volume growth will be muted amid higher product prices. Despite the easing of commodity prices, the companies have not passed on the benefit to consumers in a bid to protect margins.   InfoTech   A sharp drop in the pound and the euro of 5-6% sequentially against the dollar will likely offset the benefit of over 3% decline in the rupee against the dollar, thereby affecting the revenue growth of IT exporters. Management commentary on deal momentum, employee attrition, and forex management will be crucial.   Metals   Metal companies including ferrous and base metals are expected to report a sharp drop in earnings sequentially and year-on-year amid a fall in prices. While this will impact realisations, higher raw material costs will hurt margins.   Oil & Gas   The energy sector continued to face headwinds in the September quarter. The benchmark Singapore gross refining margin (GRM) fell sharply while petrol spreads turned negative. In addition, the growth of upstream companies was capped by windfall levies. The marketing loss on retail fuel for oil marketing companies has started moderating.   Pharma   Pharma companies are likely to post a modest performance for the quarter. There has been an easing in input cost pressures, helping with margins. The performance of India and emerging markets is expected to compensate for the price erosion in the US market.

title: 5 stocks where Anil Kumar Goel bought additional shares in Q1
summary: Goel and his spouse Seema Goel raised stakes in Nahar Spinning Mills. At the end of the June quarter, Goel held 17,64,000 shares or 4.89 per cent stake, up from 17,56,400 shares or 4.87 per cent stake. His wife, on the other hand, upped her stake to 6,16,000 shares or 1.71 per cent from 6,12,000 shares or 1.70 per cent. The Goel duo has been holding this stock at least since the June quarter of 2021.
article: Seasoned investor  Anil Kumar Goel , who owns 1 per cent or above stakes in 35 BSE listed smallcaps, was seen upping his holdings marginally in five of his portfolio stocks in the June quarter.  Goel increased his stake in  Indsil Hydro Power and Manganese  to 2.46 per cent (or 6,84,000 shares) in the June quarter from 2.34 per cent (or 6,50,000 shares) in the March quarter. Goel entered this stock in the September quarter of 2021, Trendlyne data suggests.  In the case of Nahar Capital & Financial Services, Goel increased his holding to 3,99,000 shares or 2.38 per cent from 3,94,000 shares or 2.35 per cent. Goel had entered this stock in the December quarter with a 2.05 per cent stake purchase.  Goel and his spouse Seema Goel raised stakes in  Nahar Spinning Mills . At the end of the June quarter, Goel held 17,64,000 shares or 4.89 per cent stake, up from 17,56,400 shares or 4.87 per cent stake. His wife, on the other hand, upped her stake to 6,16,000 shares or 1.71 per cent from 6,12,000 shares or 1.70 per cent. The Goel duo has been holding this stock at least since the June quarter of 2021.  Precot and  TCPL Packaging  are two other stocks where Goel increased stakes. While Seema Goel stayed put with her 1,80,000 shares or 1.50 per cent stake in Precot, Goel upped his stake marginally to 4,52,000 shares or 3.77 per cent in the June quarter from 4,50,414 shares or 3.75 per cent stake on a sequential basis.  In TCPL Packaging, Anil Goel stayed put at 8,28,000 shares or 9.10 per cent stake. Seema Goel, on the other hand, increased her holding in the company to 1,27,000 shares or 1.40 per cent from 1,26,000 shares or 1.38 per cent.
